questions.text: The preservative used if viscera is stored for toxicological examination in autopsy is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Saturated salt solution Toxicological viscera is preserved in a saturated solution of common salt (sodium chloride).

Highyeild:

Preservation and Preservative in a suspected case of poisoning Stomach and its contents Early part of Intestine – 30 cm of upper part of Intestine Liver – 200 to 300 grams / not less than 500g Kidney – one half of each kidney – kidney is out along its convex border (surface) If we collect one full kidney – sometimes it may be a failed kidney. Preservatives used for stomach, intestine, liver and kidney are saturated solutions of saline. Most Commonly used and best preservative is the saturated solution of saline. It is Contraindicated in corrosive acids and bases, aconite -Here we can use Rectified spirit. Rectified spirit is Contraindicated in Alcohol, phenol, phosphorus and kerosene poisoning. Stomach and intestine in one bottles Liver and kidney in one bottle Blood and urine in different bottles Blood – Ideal 30ml is collected, but min of 10 ml to be collected to detect poison (or) a drug. Blood is taken from peripheral veins, before opening the body, particularly femoral vein (or) External iliac vein .Avoid taking blood from the heart. Preservative for blood is Na/K fluoride 10mg/ml of blood. Potassium oxalate 3mg/ml – can be used as anticoagulant Urine → 30ml For urine, we can use Na/K fluoride (or) thymol 100mg (or) 1 ml of conc. Hcl Tissues In case of estimation of enzymes are preserved in a thermos flask containing liquid nitrogen For virology organs are preserved in 10% formalin For histopath organs are preserved in 10% formalin For anatomical specimens shall be preserved in 40 % formalin. Additional viscera to be Removed a. Heart – digitalis, strychnine →heart is preserved b. Brain – strychnine, organophosphorus, opium, CO, cyanide, barbiturates c. Spinal cord – Strychnine , Gelsemium d. CSF – Alcohol e. Bile – Narcotic drugs, cocaine, barbiturates f. Lungs – In volatile / gaseous poisons Lungs are to be preserved in Nylon bags and are heat sealed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Glycerine- can be used for virological studies. Option B.Rectified spirit-Saturated salt solution is Contraindicated in corrosive acids and bases, aconite- Here we can use Rectified spirit. Option C.Formalin- For toxicological analysis,specimens are never preserved in alcohol, formalin, or bile salt. In fact, formalin denatures proteins and chemical toxins and would interfere with the detection of poisons during chemical analysis.

questions.text: In Alleged history of gunshot injury. There is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound Dirt collar. What is the range?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Close shot entry wound Burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound are features of close shot entry. And may occur in c ontact shots when the muzzle end is not pressed firmly or is loosened by recoil, flame, gas and soot may escape sideways and soil the adjoining skin. Grease collar or dirt collar is seen at firearm entry wounds. It is a black colored ring lining the entrance wound on the skin. It is produced by removal of substances from the bullet as it grazes through the skin.

questions.text: Punishment for perjury is under which section IPC ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

193 IPC Perjury- the act of telling a lie in a c ourt of law is punishable under S. 193 IPC. Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years , and shall also be liable to fine ; and whoever intentionally gives or fabricates false evidence in any other case, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years , and shall also be liable to fine.

Highyeild:

PENAL PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO MEDICAL PRACTICE: I.P.C. S. 52 Nothing is said to be done in good faith which is done without due care and attention. S. 191 Giving false evidence. S. 192 Fabricating false evidence. S. 193 Punishment for false evidence (imprisonment up to seven years). S. 194 Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of capital offence (imprisonment up to ten years ). S. 195 Giving or fabricating false evidence with intent to procure conviction of offence (imprisonment for life or imprisonment. ) S. 197 Issuing or signing false certificates ( imprisonment up to seven years ). S. 201 Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offenders ( imprisonment up to ten years ). S. 202 Intentional omission to give information of offence by person bound to inform ( imprisonment up to six months ). S. 203 Giving false information respecting an offence committed (imprisonment up to two years ). S. 204 Destruction of document to prevent its production as evidence (imprisonment up to two years). S. 269 Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life (imprisonment up to six months ). S. 270 Malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life (imprisonment up to two years ). S. 284 Negligent conduct with respect to poisonous substances .(imprisonment upto 6 months ).

questions.text: A child is having Battered baby syndrome how will you identify:
questions.correct_answer: C. Multiple Injuries at different ages
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multiple Injuries at different ages Battered child is one which has received repetitive non accidental physical injuries by the parent or guardian .The child will have all types of injuries of all ages.

Highyeild:

BATTERED BABY SYNDROME - Also called Caffey’s syndrome, child abuse syndrome. Battered child is one which has received repetitive non accidental physical injuries by the parent or guardian . In addition to physical injuries, there is deprivation of love, care, affection and nutrition. Criteria for diagnosis - Obvious discrepancy between the history given & nature of injury on the body Undue / unexplained delay in seeking medical intervention for injury Injuries of all ages Features- At < 3 years, but no age exemption Slightly male preponderance Low socioeconomic status → may be unwanted child Injuries- All types of mechanical injuries – Abrasions,lacerations, contusions, incised wound seen. Fractures Cigarette injuries Infantile whiplash syndrome- Lifts the child at the armpit and shakes the child vigorously, thereby head of the child is thrown into whiplash motion Most Common findings – subdural haemorrhage Also called shaken baby syndrome Butterfly bruises- due to pinching effect Cause of death- Head injury Rupture of abdominal organs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B and D. Though all injuries can be seen , Option C. is more specific in battered baby syndrome.

Solution:

Myocardium State of the muscles in a dead body when they become stiff or rigid with some degree of shortening is called Rigor mortis .. All muscles of the body are involved i.e. voluntary or involuntary . However, it does not start in all muscles simultaneously (Nysten’s rule). Involuntary muscles (heart) are involved first than voluntary muscles.

Highyeild:

RIGOR MORTIS - Decreased in ATP Starts when ATP is 85% of normal Maximum when ATP is 15% of normal Order of appearance Involuntary muscles – myocardium – 1hr Voluntary muscles Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups Eyelids > neck > jaw > facial m/s > chest > shoulder + UL > Abdomen > pelvis + LL > fingers and toes Rule of 12 Rigor mortis takes 12 hours to appear on all parts of body, remains for 12 hours and disappears by 12 hours. Disappears in the same order as appeared. Rigor appears and disappear early: Convulsive death Tetanus Electrocution Strychnine Lightening Chronic debilitating disease: TB Cholera Malignancy Rigor appears and disappear late: Sudden death Poisoning: arsenic carbon monoxide Mercury Rigor does not appear: Septicemia Fetus born within 7 month of gestation Rigor appears early, disappear late: Cyanide poisoning Drowning

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,C and D. are incorrect. Because Involuntary muscles are affected first in Rigor mortis.

Extraedge:

CADAVERIC SPASM- A group of voluntary muscles which are active & contracted at the moment of death. They continue to be in the same state of contraction, after death for a few hours. Cataleptic Rigidity → Instantaneous rigor Mechanism not known exactly Mostly Neurogenic Sudden violent deaths Cadaveric spasm cannot be mimicked by anything else. Medicolegal importance- Helps to know about cause of death Can differentiate antemortem and postmortem drowning.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is not contraindicated after ingestion of which acid:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbolic acid The only absolute contraindication is c orrosive poisoning i.e. alkalis, mineral acid, vegetable acid and organic acids ( except carbolic acid).

Highyeild:

Gastric lavage must be done (except when contraindicated) irrespective of whether vomiting has occurred or not, to prevent aspiration of content. Water or normal saline most commonly used Potassium permanganate used for oxidizable poisons(Organophosphorous) Calcium gluconate for oxalates Sodium thiosulphate for Absolute contraindication- c orrosive poisoning e. alkalis, mineral acid, vegetable acid and organic acids ( except carbolic acid) In carbolic acid there is swelling of the stomach mucosa so the stomach wall is thickened ( leathery stomach ) thus no fear of stomach perforation. Gastric lavage can be done and activated charcoal can be given. Other contraindications: Volatile poison Convulsants Upper GI varices Pregnancy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,B and D. are corrosives and are absolute contraindications for gastric lavage.
